title: How does one overcome depression and anxiety? - Quora

response.answer_text: To my knowledge, there are two types of depression: situational depression, caused by a traumatic life event like a death, a divorce, or a terrible breakup, and chronic depression, which is caused by a consistent lack of serotonin in the brain. There’s an important distinction between situational and chronic depression, as one is temporary, and one is forever, and coping mechanisms do differ depending on this. I have severe chronic depression, and have had it since I hit puberty, which was when I noticed that the world just seemed muted, hollow and dull. I was diagnosed with MDD when I was 13, started going to therapy when I was 15 (I went for close to 4 years), and also started medicating for depression when I was 17. Throughout this time, life gave me a couple punches in the face, and I have also dealt with situationally fuelled depressive episodes as well over the years. Here’s what I’ve found helps me the most for combatting my depression and associated anxiety, based on my therapy, independent research, and conclusions I’ve come to on my own: Refuse to be embarrassed about your depression. When I stopped being private about my depression among my friends and family, they were better able to understand how I was feeling and to not take cancellations or behaviour differences based on my mental illness personally. I even coined a term for when I was feeling particularly fragile: my Down Days. Now I can tell my friends, my parents, or my boyfriend that I’m having a Down Day and they’ll understand, and will interact with me accordingly.Start thinking about yourself as if there are two of you, your depression, and who you actually are, and assume that it’s typically your depression who’s doing the thinking. Once I began to separate myself from my mental illness, I started being kinder with myself and stopped being angry with myself for being depressed. I wouldn’t tell myself that I was stupid if I had type 1 diabetes, so why would I tell myself that because I have depression? This coping mechanism also helps you to become better at gauging when thoughts you’re having during a depressive episode are actually realistic or if they’re intrusive, destructive thoughts.And while you’re at it, stop assuming that you can move mountains when you’re depressed. I would be proud as hell of myself if I were to get a full day’s work done, or cook a fly meal, or even took a shower where I washed my hair if I had the flu, and being in a depressive episode is the mental equivalent of the flu. When I am in a depressive episode, now that I’m a depression veteran, I know to give myself a pat on the back even if the only thing I do one day is brush my teeth. Having the same expectations of yourself when you’re depressed as when you’re healthy will only make you feel worse, and will probably cause you to spiral.Make. Your. Bed. When I’m depressed, remaining completely stagnant just sends me spiralling even further, so I make a point of forcing myself to at the very least make my bed. It takes 3 minutes, it doesn’t have to look like a hotel maid did it, but it makes you feel more capable, which is a huge step in the right direction. I’ve typically found that once I made my bed, I’ll feel a bit more confident to brush my teeth, which will lead to me showering, then maybe eating, then probably leaving my house, then starting to feel better, which very quickly becomes a HUGE win.If you’re able to, disregard societal time expectations as much as possible. A huge reason that I work for myself is to have full control over my time because I am mentally ill, and I need to be able to work around my illness. If I’m having a Down Day, I am completely okay with fucking around all morning reading Quora, petting my dog and doing tiny little cleaning projects to get me out of my Down Day mindset and starting work at 4 PM— getting upset with myself for not starting work at 9 AM does me no favours. It truly does not matter if you’re getting shit done at 8 AM or 11 PM; you’re getting it done, and you should be proud of yourself.Don’t be afraid to discuss medication options with your doctor. I know quite a few people that view antidepressants as a crutch, or a bandaid solution, but I disagree. After a few years of therapy, I felt that I needed another way to better my mental health. My doctor prescribed me an SSRI (trintillex), and it changed my fucking life. I remember walking down the street to my high school about a week after I started taking it (SSRI’s take 1–2 weeks to become effective), and bursting into tears because I realized that I was just smiling and admiring how blue the sky was. I hadn’t done that since I was 9 years old.But do not under any circumstances self-medicate. During a severe bought of situational depression and most likely undiagnosed PTSD (I held my grandfather’s hand and watched him die, and then my stepdad skipped town not one week later, thanks Life), I became a wee bit too fond of Xanax, resulting in me deciding to take a gap year from university after waking up one morning and realizing I hadn’t been sober in 72 hours. That feeling was without a doubt one of the most depressing things I’ve experienced in my life. Just don’t go there. It’s not worth it.If you’re feeling suicidal, find a reason that you can’t kill yourself right now. I can’t count on my two hands the times where I’ve removed the plastic bag from my head, put the razor away or put the pills back in the bottle because I needed to get something done for work, or I hadn’t replied to a text message, or I needed to get a small task done for someone else. Similar to how smokers are told to wait 10 minutes to have a cigarette because the craving will go away, your suicide “craving” will subside.If you can’t find a reason not to commit suicide, take a few minutes to read about what survivors of suicide attempts have to say about it. Let’s be realistic here: no one who really, really wants to commit suicide is going to call a suicide prevention hotline. Last time I wanted to kill myself, I wasn’t exactly jonesing to chat to a stranger about it on the phone. Reading about suicide survivors’ experiences is a much more accessible way for a suicidal person to expand their perspective, at least from personal experience. It’s not only comforting to know that you aren’t alone, but it also scares you into inaction, which is of course a good thing in this situation. This article is great.Lastly, fight depression anti-logic with logic. I run a successful business as a 21 year old, have great friends, a caring family, I’m smart, I have a boyfriend who loves me, and I’m a model, but my depression has had me convinced more times than I’d like to admit that I’m a failure, I’m ugly, I’m a loser, that no one cares about me, and that death is my only option as a reprieve from the mental anguish I’m feeling. I have found that asking myself simple questions like why do I feel that no one likes me?, or why do I feel like I’m an ugly, disgusting waste of space?, and working backwards to unravel the thought makes it much easier to realize that my mentally ill thoughts aren’t founded in logic. You’ll also start to become more aware of your emotional patterns, so you can combat your depression before you even get to a Down Day. This is one of the foundations of cognitive behaviour therapy!I sincerely hope that one person might find these coping mechanisms helpful, because I understand how hobbling depression and anxiety can be. If anyone has any advice that could be added to this list, please add your thoughts in the comments! Depression sucks, but you don’t. You got this.

As someone who has had to overcome a miserable life full of anxiety and depression and who was raised by a parent and a grandparent who were chronically negative and miserable, I think I can weigh in on this by telling you a story. My chronically sad father was believed to be a hypochondriac and I was horrified to find that my symptoms were similar to his—chronic pain and fatigue and a negative outlook on life—and my treatment by doctors and others was similar to the way they treated him, scornful for such weakness. Because he was seen with such disrespect, I struggled valiantly for three decades to hide, work around, or otherwise give the appearance of good health and positivity, all while being anxious, depressed, and thoroughly miserable. Then, in trying to get enough exercise, I fell off a horse. It left me in even worse pain and almost unable to walk, unable to work, and feeling like the accident was further proof of my incompetence and that I really was, “just like your Dad.” It forced me to stop running and accept the fact that it was true, I was just like him, always in pain, always suffering, always, always tripping over my own feet somehow, a worthless weakling, and I didn’t see any way to end it. Knowing that after we die we can see more clearly, my thought was that he, having passed, would know how to stop this so, in tears, I silently asked him, “Dad, what should I do now?” To my startled amazement, I heard his voice saying, “We begin by not feeling sorry for ourselves.” There is such wisdom in this that I was startled. Do you see it? We have pain, yes, we have attitude from others because they don’t understand, yes, we have anxiety, yes, and we have depression, yes—but we begin by not feeling sorry for ourselves. It is that feeling sorry for ourselves that others find so distasteful, so tiresome. As it turned out, I was diagnosed with real, not imaginary, disorders (fibromyalgia and osteoarthritis and a fracture of the spine) and I realized then that my Dad has also been misunderstood because he had all the symptoms of fibromyalgia too, so he suffered all those years alone, with everyone believing he was merely making it up for attention. But this is the way life works. Yes, you have depression and anxiety but we have to stop feeling sorry for ourselves enough to realize that no one in your family wants to hear it. This is just normal. To ask them to feel sorry for you is to ask them to join you in misery, to agree, “yes, you are so miserable. How sad!” But that is not the right attitude but is actually a form of self-indulgence. The real answer is to stop feeling sorry for yourself and take some responsibility to overcome it. This includes seeing a therapist, getting some anti-depressants if necessary, or whatever it takes to get on the road to recovery. Anxiety and depression are common, common, common so having them don’t make you special or deserving of special sympathy. It is like my father’s spirit said, we have to stop feeling sorry for ourselves and take action toward finding solutions. What helped me was Transcendental Meditation and therapy. TM removes the underlying stresses that are the cause of weakness and suffering and it wakes up new strengths and improved ways of dealing with life. I eventually learned how to shake off depression and to ignore anxiety. Even though anyone who had lived my life would have been depressed and anxious, all that finally went away because I stopped feeling sorry for myself, faced reality head on, and worked to change. Your question includes saying that you have done no harm to others, but I disagree. I think when we expect others to listen to us being miserable we are doing harm to them and harm to our relationships. It is unfair that you expect your family to feel sorry for you when you are not doing anything to help yourself, don’t you agree?

I don't believe that "overcome" is the best way to phrase it. We don't (ok-shouldn't) rattle off ways for people to "overcome" grief or cancer or MS… We simply find ways to heal - and hopefully go into remission, or stay more healthy and happy long term. So- with semantics out of the way… There is no one size fits all solution for healing when it comes to depression and anxiety. There are immensely varying reasons for these things happening in the first place: trauma, chemical/hormonal imbalances, exhaustion, health, things within our control, things outside of our control, horrible relationships, loss, just being within a sometimes cruel and unfair world. One person I know had horrible depression and was told that it was "spiritual," and that one of the best ways to "cure" depression was to do more for people. (This was many years ago - not unlike "curing homosexuality" that many purport today…) The irony is that this person was one of the most giving, serving people I have ever known. They were constantly beating themselves up about needing to do more and be perfect, etc. I went through a lengthy bout of anxiety about 10 or so years ago. I would keep everything "together" during the day, manage what I needed to, and every time I would FINALLY be able to fall asleep I would wake up in a full blown panic attack within seconds/minutes. It would happen all night, endlessly. I went to the ER two or three times over a few months believing that I was having severe heart problems before a dr finally said "are you under a tremendous amount of stress?" My answer was that I was under no more stress than most people (so obviously I should be able to deal with it, right? Wrong.)… In retrospect, there are some situations in my life I should have ended and left far far behind at that point, but * in my case * just knowing that it was anxiety/panic attacks helped begin the journey to combatting them effectively. It didn't take them away, but it did enable me to create some specific coping mechanisms over time, and now I recognize the signs - but have also come to realize over the past couple of years that panic attacks are just one of MANY signs of anxiety- they are a horrific one though, so not having that to deal with constantly is a tremendous relief. (Rabbit Trail → I didn't realize I'd actually had small panic attacks even during my school years… I had no idea. We didn't talk about those types of things a tremendous amount in my household at that point - but that was also the time period. There is much more awareness now, thank God. Sometimes it's helpful to look back to what may have been a underlying difficulty all along, even without realizing it!) I know phenomenal people - the best teachers and parents and overall human beings in the world - who deal with depression and anxiety constantly. A large number of them actually. Some have had long term relief, some are on a constant regimen of pills and/or strict exercise and dietary habits (none of these are a magical cure-all btw), others decided to get away for a bit to rest. Some have taken "spiritual journeys" (think a week or two at a monastery - in fact, this is on my own list for the future), others said that the electro-shock (though I hate writing that) therapy gave them their lives back, truly good therapists can be key for many, and some healed after leaving a bad situation or cutting off a root source of the underlying problem. (There can be a whole lot of anger / grief that surfaces while dealing with the process too. Never ever ever ever tell someone that they are being bitter or not moving forward or need to "simply release the anger to heal," or they will want to pummel you- even if they don't.) Short version → Every cause and every solution or coping mechanism is different because humanity and circumstances are incredibly diverse. There is no perfect time line. (If it is any comfort at all [this varies by person as well], it is very common, and thankfully the "stigma" that once surrounded it societally and religiously is being shattered.)

(Edvard Munch Anxiety [1]) I want to answer this from the perspective of C.G. Jung’s depth psychological approach because in my experience, both personal and professional, this way of seeing into anxiety and depression offers not only deep insight into the problem, but also, profound healing. What I mean by healing is that you embrace and transcend the anxiety and depression by consciously working with them, rather than alleviate the symptoms with medication. Let’s start with a quote from Jung, which may strike you as insensitive or arrogant without context, but I promise you, the quote is rich in meaning and it comes from Jung’s own experience with depression and anxiety: The foundation of all mental illness is the unwillingness to experience legitimate suffering. What he means by legitimate suffering is that anxiety and depression are actually symptoms of a deeper problem, a problem of the soul which has not been adequately metabolized, psychologically speaking. (painting, Edward Munch, The Scream [2])  Now, the medical approach to anxiety and depression will say, “it’s a chemical imbalance” and the CBT approach will say, “it’s thought distortion”. The medical approach treats the chemical imbalance with pharmacology. Cognitive behavioral therapy, holding that the distorted beliefs or thoughts cause negative actions or feelings, works to change those distorted patterns by reinforcing not-so-distorted patterns. Psychological suffering is not just a mental or chemical imbalance. To think of it in this way is to fall victim to the misconception of the mind/body split. We are whole beings. Whenever we suffer, that suffering expresses itself at every level. Anxiety and depression affects the whole person: psycho-spiritually, physically, mentally, and physiologically. The signs and symptoms of anxiety and depression will manifest at every level. [3] From the Jungian point of view, the problem with anxiety or depression, as with any form of psychological suffering, is that your whole life system is out of balance. My experience with anxiety and depression Whenever I talk about Jung’s psychology, I am not speaking as a Jungian, per se. I am speaking from my experience with his approach to life. I never say anything is so, just because Jung said it was so. I dealt with psychological issues for decades of my life. I was one of those people who looked like I had it all together, but on the inside, felt like I was falling apart. I could easily point to my childhood experiences and say, “this is why”, but that did nothing to change the fact that I suffered from severe anxiety and depression. Anxiety and depression have an irrational factor that will not yield to intellectualizing your problems, i.e., reducing your problems to “this is why” or “this is the cause”. In order to get to that irrational factor behind your anxiety and depression, you have to ask yourself some difficult questions. Asking the Right Questions About Why You Suffer  (Painting, Edvard Munch, Separation [4]) In order to work with the irrational factor, you have to ask yourself not, what is the cause of my suffering, but rather, what is the purpose of my suffering? Again, I draw from Jung: The wise man … will ask himself: Who am I that all this should happen to me? To find the answer to this fateful question he will look into his own heart. What does it mean - to look into your heart and ask this fateful question about the nature of the things that have happened to you? Who am I that all this should happen to me? It is not the same as falling into the unproductive, why me syndrome. Here’s another quote from Jung: I am not what happened to me. I am what I choose to become… That is, what you choose to become DESPITE your suffering - or even - because of your suffering. Now this is a challenge because a lot of people don’t like who they are. If that is you, it is only because you don’t see yourself clearly. Believe me, you’ll find something special in there, something precious that has endured …  (Van Gough, Self-Portrait with Bandaged Ear [5] Surrendering Yourself You have to find a way to appreciate yourself - love yourself even - and man, is that hard to do for some of us. You have to wade through a lot of self-loathing in order to find what is truly precious in yourself. Sometimes, it’s unconscious, other times, it’s right in our face. For me personally, I had to surrender to some disgusting experiences in my life. There was no medication or thought-reprogramming that could change any of it. I had to ask myself that same fateful question that I encouraged you to ask yourself. Who am I that all this should happen to me? … and then, dig really deep to find my answers. I have lost clients because they were simply unable to make the transition from holding on to their suffering and sense of injustice to asking themselves what their suffering could mean for their soul’s path. If you can find a way to be open to those kinds of questions, then already your anxiety and depression starts to shift. Find the Meaning in Your Suffering  (Painting, Edvard Munch, Melancholy [6] ) Finding meaning in your suffering - this is very difficult for a lot of people. Again comes the question: Who am I that all this should happen to me? Yes, I keep repeating it because I want you to hear it - really hear it echoing from the depths of your soul. As I said, the question of Jung’s has nothing to do with falling into states of self-indulgent pity. Self-indulgent pity is illegitimate suffering. Don’t read that wrong. For some of us, those states of self-indulgent pity are part of our process. Many people come from a past where empathy or compassion simply did not exist, so we have to find it for ourselves, in ourselves. But the key to not falling into it is consciousness. Conscious suffering is the key. I juxtapose identifying with your suffering and conscious suffering. The difference is this: I am depressed or I am anxious (identification) and This is depression or this is anxiety (conscious suffering). You see, by doing this you immediately separate you from the state of anxiety or depression. Conscious suffering is what Jung meant by legitimate suffering. Anxiety, Depression, and Legitimate Suffering Basically, if you say that you “suffer from anxiety and depression” and leave it there, then that would fall under the category of “unwillingness to bear legitimate suffering.” Again, don’t get me wrong. No doubt that you suffer, but it’s not from your anxiety and depression. It’s that other thing that you won’t look at it: that underlying pain, humiliation, or rejection in your life. Here’s a twist: your anxiety and depression are an attempt at self-healing. Just as a fever raises your body temperature in order to kill an infection, so your psyche produces its own symptoms to kill a psychological infection. Going Inward: the Battle for Your Life  (Painting, Alexander Louis Leloir, Jacob Wrestling with the Angel[7]) In a personal letter, Jung once wrote of his own depression When the darkness grows denser, I would penetrate to its very core and ground, and would not rest until amid the pain a light appeared to me, for in excessu affectus (in an excess of affect or passion) Nature reverses herself. I would turn in rage against myself and with the heat of my rage I would melt my lead. I would renounce everything and engage in the lowest activities should my depression drive me to violence. I would wrestle with the dark angel until he dislocated my hip. For he is also the light and the blue sky which he withholds from me. This going inward begins with your state of mind: the feeling tone of the anxiety or the depression itself. Getting to the Core of Anxiety and Depression  (painting, Vincent van Gough, Sorrowing Old Man (At Eternity's Gate) [8]) It might be helpful here for me to share my own insight from working with the structure of anxiety and depression: Depression is a withdrawal of your vital life forceIt steals your vitality by sucking your life force into your depths. It’s that darkness that you have to enter. That’s why you have no energy.Find the place where that energy is stored, for example, a lost or rejected part of yourself.Give it your attention, even if that’s just by looking at it.Eventually, you will gain access to your vitality again.Anxiety splits your life force such that it scatters and becomes useless for anything other than falling into fear and worry.There will be a center around which all of your fears and worries circle.it’s not money, job, relationships - all of that is just on the surfaceFind out what that core fear is, for example, self-doubt or worthlessnessUnresolved terror, rage, grief, or any other emotions that we push aside or suppress – these are the places we have to go in order to get to the roots of depression and anxiety. Once you find yourself in the midst of those emotions, you then have to turn them inside out, as Jung suggests below in his letter to a depressed friend. [9] Relief, Restoration, and Healing from Anxiety and Depression  (Vincent van Gough, Landscape with Wheat Sheaves and Rising Moon[10] ) What I have been talking about throughout this post is psycho-dynamics. In essence, when our psychic energy flows outward, we cultivate and animate outer life. When psychic energy flows inward, we cultivate and animate inner life. Both worlds need our energy and attention. When we deprive either of their right to life, then we suffer the consequences of that deprivation. If depression takes your life force from the things you love, then turn inward and search for where that life force is locked away, waiting for release. Tend to that lost place in yourself and it will release that vitality back into your life. If anxiety scatters your life force into fear and worry, pull that energy into yourself. Sit with that tension until it reveals the true nature of your pain. Again, tend to that unresolved aspect of yourself and you will regain a sense of control in your life. Happy new year and all the best…. Immediately stop relentlessly identifying with the beast.With addiction, you must first accept and name your beast as it is: addiction. Reminding yourself that you are an alcoholic or an addict is a cognitive note not to step into a liquor store. It is a reminder that you are susceptible to the vices that trigger you, and it is intended to steer you clear of them. Saying “I have depression” and “I have anxiety” are not analogous to this mnemonic. When you repetitively say “I have depression”, or “I have anxiety”, you are spinning yourself into a cycle of inducing the aforementioned negative mental state. Addiction is physical, depression and anxiety are primarily mental. Don’t conflate these two.Stop giving up on small, innocuous wins.When you eat a chicken breast instead of a bag of Doritos, you win. And I could give a f*ck less about your body at this point. If you tackle minute anxiety-inducing circumstances one-by-one, even if you only partially succeed, you are slowly rearranging your ability to introduce uncomfortable circumstance into your pattern of acceptable behaviour, and you are winning. Start envisioning every action you take as having a direct inflection on the chemical makeup of your mind, because at this point every action does.Know that decadence resolves to disappointment. Every single time.Depression and anxiety cases have a tendency to indulge in the antithesis of the aforementioned small, innocuous wins. A tub of Ben & Jerry’s and drinking cheap vodka often sounds like a great idea. These people become the the progeny of raw escapism. At some point soon, decadence disappears, and we become not just the physical result of poor choices, but we fractionally adopt a neurological affinity for indulging in such a negative habit again. This makes our situation doubly hard to escape. It’s important to end this cycle immediately.Accept your f*cking isolation over unsavory social saturation.The Law of Fives reminds me that we are the average of the 5 people we hang around the most. If you have depression and you indulge often in escapist tendencies with an unsavory 5, at least accept that you are not going to fix neither your depression, nor theirs. You are their problem just as much as they are yours, and that should upset you. If you have anxiety, and you often resolve to habitually victimized conversations about the crippling incarceration of your inescapable fears, then you are not going to fix neither your anxiety, nor theirs.Know that the richest man is rich of mind.I recognized from an early age that the biggest agent of my depressive or anxious state was my self-perceived lack of worldly value. Today, whenever I am feeling low, or worried about my future, I study. It is important to have an interest of study, of course, but when none was found, I let interests find me. I would watch the science channel. I would scour online forums. I would use this ridiculously infinite pool of unending knowledge called the Internet and I would just browse. Today, I still do this. I still seek worldly value in the form of a rich and malleable mind. I know that my career path may change many times through the course of my life. I plant tiny seeds such as this Quora account and I let time sow small harvests in each field. I attempt to practice stranger and more frustratingly complex concepts until I am accustomed to this habitual mental difficulty. So much of any career path is simply being comfortable with complexity. That is something we can always practice. That can make us rich of mind.Grade the effective benefit of every new form of habit and self-talk.You can see, I’ve listed what works for me. What works for me is somewhere near the realm of negative reinforcement, which may seem odd, but that’s my out. I don’t coddle myself. I don’t victimize myself. I recognize Hell, I walk through it, and I build a ladder step-by-step. Maybe this isn’t your strategy. Whatever you try, you must grade. You must sincerely question the effectiveness of new habits or you are wasting your time. Scientists don’t invent new cures by shooting blindly in the dark on every chemical iteration. They use data from previous experiments, and they adjust accordingly. You must operate quite the same. Everyone is different, no one has the perfect combination of outs for you. You must use your vast array of personal experience and look diligently and earnestly for those small, innocuous wins.Look up. No, literally — Look up.Try this… Walk along any city street nowadays and notice how many people run through life with their heads down. Just stand there. Count them. Imagine yourself walking exactly as they are. Imagine someone looking at you. Ew.It’s not a cute metaphor; practice actually looking up. Notice things you haven’t noticed before. Identify the types of scaffolding on buildings. Spot the windows that need washing. Notice the clumsy, sheepish behavior of everyone cruising down the sidewalk on autopilot, staring at their phones. Part of breaking undesired habits is just beginning new, monotonous ones.Part of changing our outlook on life is physically changing our perspective. Looking up is a fantastic start. I look up because it makes me feel new. It makes me recognize how much simply happens. It makes me stand out for reasons that I’ve now become comfortable with. When I look up, I acknowledge that life exists. I appreciate the sheer persistence of beauty that will endure despite my being here or not. I feel like I am small, but I appreciate the grandeur of opportunity that renders me such a beautiful size. ❤️ Augie

For me, I opted out for taking anti-depressants because I was prescribed two different ones, they both made me having sucidal thoughts within few days. It gave me so many anxiety too. I had anxiety attacks and passed out 4 times within 9 days. I was sent to the emergency on the last one, because I passed out in the public. Hopelessness and numbness were my symptoms of my depression. I was exhausted. I slept a lot. I remembered I slept 3 days straight once without eating or showering. I felt so guilty about that. I couldn’t do that anymore and I knew I needed to something. So I started to think of a plan. Nutrition. I need to eat even I don’t want to. Health foods. At first, it was hard because I didn’t want to cook or go out. So I mostly ate boiled eggs, fruits and yogurt. Drink water, that was hard for me too. So when I had motivation at some moments, I drank a full glass or 2 to compensate times I didn’t.Self care. No more skipping shower. But this is not enough. If I lived in an unorganized place, I will get frustrated and tired. So I cleaned up my apartment when I had a good moment and I asked my friend to help too.Vitamins. I took vitamin B complex, omega 3 and 5-HTP.Tried to answer phone calls and reply messages. I turned off my phone a lot when I was in depression. One of friend actually came to check up on me, but I shut the door on him. It was a horrible feeling.Sit outside for half and hour in the afternoon when the weather was nice. I actually didn’t see “color” during my depression, but I knew it was good me. So if I wanted to get out of that, I needed to do it.Short walk. A small sweat feels good.I did the above steps for 2–3 weeks, my sleeping cycle got better. But I still felt hopeless and numb. (Not sad). So I started work on more than basic self care. I started journaling and worked on weekly planning. It helped a lot. It unloaded my thoughts from my mind. More organized, I was very forgetful during my depression.Set goals and wrote them down literally. Set timeline and wrote down exactly how I can archive them. Small, short and long term goals. That helped a lot to improve my hopelessness feeling.Meditation. It was hard at the beginning. I started with 5 mins guided meditate first, then 10 mins, 15 mins, 20 mins and 30 mins.Overcame depression and anxiety was the hardest thing I have done in my life. I was lucky. I had a very good support system. My family and friends didn’t judge me. They also understood depression is not something you can just slap out of it. They were so patient with me and didn’t make me feel guilty when I shut them out.

Depression & anxiety are both a mental disorder that is based upon negative thoughts, that can result in a mental or hormonal imbalance. There is no one size fits all for defeating either disorder, which can often be linked. Anxiety is fear based, often fear of inadequacy. I was depressed for most of my life. For me, it was a negative self image, partially driven by anxiety that I didn’t even realize I had until after I overcame my depression, and was able to self diagnose. The seeds for my depression were planted early in my childhood. My parents divorced when I was about 4 years old. My family was very dysfunctional. My two oldest siblings went to live with their dad, while we (the younger siblings) were sent to foster care. When my mother finally got her life together and got us back, she was working 2 jobs and left us in the care of my sister. My oldest brother was psychologically abusive, and there was not much my mom or sister could do to stop it. In fact, my sister was as much a target as my brothers and I were. We we’re all dirt poor, as was my dad, so we didn’t have much of anything. All this led to low self esteem. Being diagnosed with hyperthyroidism when I was twenty didn’t help. It caused me to be 30 - 40 pounds under weight, which caused my face to be taught, and made my eyes looked like they bulged. So just as I was getting out on my own, my appearance added to my low self esteem. I turned to weed & alcohol to numb the misery until it just became overwhelming. I wound up going from job to job, getting angry at every one but myself, blaming everyone else for everything that was wrong with the world, and my life. I was angry and hated the world, at least that was the way I acted. The truth was that I hated myself, and that was why I behaved the way that I did. That was the reason for the self destructive behavior. Eventually, I began to recognize that I did not respect myself. I couldn’t be the man that I wanted to be and felt powerless to change. I eventually turned to God through prayer. Then I started reading the Bible and watched a lot of different pastors on Christian networks. This helped to build faith in God, but not in myself, because I recognized I could never live up to those standards. But there was a lot in the Bible that helped change the pattern of my thoughts, and the way that I was thinking. Eventually, due to what was going on in the country, I started reading about the founding fathers, the Declaration of Independence, and the laws of nature & nature’s God. I began studying a lot of libertarian stuff too, like Ayn Rand & FA Hayek. Everything I was learning gave me insight into who I was, and who I wanted to be, and trying to figure out how to bridge that gap. It began with taking responsibility for my life, owning my mistakes, and recognizing the world for what it is and learning to live in that world rather than the world as I want it to be. My perspective on life has changed. I don’t drink anymore, and I quit smoking weed. I’ve begun to eat healthier and to exercise. I’ve also begun to learn not to put all that pressure on myself to meet a standard that I cannot meet. Instead, I’ve learned to love myself for who I am, and to be the best person that I can be, no matter how imperfect that person is. I am much better than I used to be, and hope that I can continue to learn & grow to be closer to the man that I want to be. The most oft repeated prayer request is that God will continue His creation of me into the man He created me to be. From there, I just trust Him to fulfill His promise to complete me. That helps with the anxiety. So the the answer to the question of what is the best treatment for depression & anxiety is #1. Faith #2. Change the way you think #3. Accept the world and yourself as you are. You didn’t create yourself, and you didn’t create the world. The best that you can do is be the best version of yourself that you can be, and hope that will make the world a better place as well. We are what we are. We are human, which means we aren’t perfect. The world we live in is not perfect. But it is beautiful, and so are we. We just have to learn to appreciate the beauty of who we are by being our best. And when we come up short, ask God’s forgiveness, and then forgive ourselves, and take steps to learn from our mistakes. Never forget that when God is finished with us, we will be another of His masterpieces. Till then, we are still a work in progress.

45 minutes and counting. It’s been 45 minutes and still, my B.P. is through the roof. My heartbeat count is infinity beats per minute. 1...2...3… Gosh! I literally can’t count my heartbeats. Just stop it. Stop it somehow! I want to stop this right now. Please! What’d you do if you ever got an anxiety attack for an hour? I panicked. More. I have had a couple of anxiety attacks in the past few months, but this was it. This was THE anxiety attack I ever had. I remember the date. 31.03.2017. Somehow it ended. I knew the trigger. I was just denying of admitting that she’s the trigger. That’s the thing - we deny our triggers first. Period. I looked at myself in the mirror. I had grown a fat belly. My face looked chubby. And I was clearly overweight. Depression changes your physique. It either makes you underweight, or a lot of times like it made me, overweight. I could count the people I could rely on, whom I could call my ‘friends’, on my fingers. Not because everyone hated me. Not at least at that time. But because I had locked myself in solitude and away from the world, in the past couple of months.  I was lucky. I was lucky to come across the right people at the right time in my life. It’s been 2 years since I had my first anxiety attack. And the moment I had it, I knew I’d have to consult a specialist. You have to “want to” get better. Within a week, via some random Facebook group, I met one of my college alumni who had done her masters in psychology. I texted her and literally used the words “I need help. Help me, please!” Pitty and desperate. But I wanted to get better. And that’s what matters. I hoped to get some reference to a psychiatrist from her. Rather she said, “Let me help you, Dipanshu. Maybe you don’t need medication. Maybe you just need to talk.” You need to open up. And so I surrendered myself. I opened up to her. I started from my childhood and had told her every incident of my life that I thought might have contributed to what I am today. Obviously, this all was confidential. And this is the first condition of any therapy session. They all are confidential. Your therapist doesn’t reveal your identity or the problem you are dealing with. Honesty goes a long way. There’s a saying that you should never lie to your doctor, your lawyer, and to your CA. After having the therapy session, I realized why. I admitted (not soon though) that I had some issues. This honest confession helped me to accelerate the therapy process. I promised myself, no matter how embarrassing or stupid an incident might be, I’d be 100% honest with my therapist. That meant confessing my weird and embarrassing set of insecurities too. But somehow I did share those as well. It takes time. You’re not going to figure out your problems in a day that took years of time to get placed inside you. It takes time. The problem you think is your ‘actual problem’, might be only a symptom or aftereffect of the real problem. Oh and this is only about figuring out what your actual problem is. Finding a solution comes after the correct diagnosis. “We must let go of impatience. Because patience is a form of acceptance and acceptance is everything.” I became empathetic. I take inspiration from the people around me. No wonder I am a writer! After having these sessions, I turned myself into a vegetarian. And somehow I’m a pet lover now. I am not sure if all the dots connect, but if I have anything in common with all this - it’s the person who took my sessions, who also happens to be a pet lover and an empathetic and kind human in general. It’s gonna come again and again. But the next time it happens, your diagnosis would probably be easier. It’s a fight. But I am no less than a fighter. So I fought back. And I am all good right now. A lot of people don't understand. And it's okay. You can understand depression, only if you've been through it. No matter how hard you try, you can't make them believe that you have any problem in the first place. Admittance and Acceptance are key factors. Admitting that I have a problem, and accepting that my existence in flawed are the two things we resist the most. In his book, Ego is the Enemy, Ryan Holiday describes 0ur ego as the greatest opponent of mankind. I consult my therapist from time to time - to get perspectives about life, psychology, etc. And she has stressed it over and over, that because I had admitted that I was in trouble, and because I had accepted the fact that I am flawed, it became easier for her to pull me out of that black hole. I thought I was depressed. Spoiler alert - I wasn't. Nonetheless, I would have had depression, if it weren't for the right people to stand by my side at the right time. But eventually, it's a long and lonely journey to battle with such a situation. And I am glad I did. Nothing else is going to help. You can't treat a heart-attack with paracetamol. Likewise, no matter how many inspirational books you read, you can't get better without opening up in a lot of cases. I was seeking medication for my anxiety attacks. All I need was someone wise enough to talk to. Like a professional therapist. That's it. Oh, and a lot of patience and courage to open up. All these were the secret ingredients that pulled me out of THE bad phase of my life. If you need someone to talk to, my inbox is always open for you. I'd try my best to respond asap. And if you're looking for professional therapy, you can try TickTalkTo (Private, Confidential and Anonymous Therapy anytime, anywhere) app available on google playstore. I have tried it myself, and it has helped me a lot. With a stick. A really big one.  In all seriousness, it can be a really tough battle. Oftentimes ongoing. The thing is though, it's all about you - the one with depression. You have to want to get better. You have to want to change and then try to make it happen. And it takes more than just one try. It's a process. All the familial support and therapists can't just beat it for you. They can certainly help, and I recommend talking to an adult you trust and seeking professional help, but they just cant beat it for you - not anymore than you can beat their problems for them. There's nothing bad or scary about therapists. They just help guide you in the right direct to a healthier, happier you. You'll just talk to them about what's been going on in your life, how you’ve been feeling, how certain things make you feel, and hopefully they'll help you learn about yourself so you can get that much closer to getting better. Personally, I actually learned a lot about myself by talking to my school social worker, counselors, and my therapist. They made me realize things about myself that I didn't necessarily like, but now that I know about them, I can handle them appropriately. They were important things for me to know about myself. Aside from directly trying to treat your mental health, it's also important to try and be physically, spiritually and emotionally healthy as well. Here are some ways you can do that: Eat well - at least one fruit or vegetable with each meal. Also aim for balanced meals. You'll feel good if you eat good food, and if your body feels good, it will help you to feel good mentally again. Exercise - take the stairs when you can, walk to places if they're close. Just don't seclude yourself to your room with the lights off and blinds shut like I did for a year. Or if you're currently doing this, try to at least open the blinds and go to the other rooms in your house a bit more until you eventually break that literal security-blanket type habit. If you exercise, your body will produce serotonin, which is a chemical that makes you feel happy. Vent - let out your emotions. If you're sad, cry if you feel like it. If you're mad, scream if you want to. I didn't get better until I finally just let myself cry out all my frustrations and tell them to someone (which took hours). I was a disgusting, sub-human mess that day, but afterwards I felt better than i had in years. I felt refreshed and lighter. Do the stuff you enjoy - personally I lost interest in essentially all the things I used to enjoy, so I had to rediscover what I liked, but it's not a big deal. Find what you enjoy, and do it. You deserve it. Try to enjoy things again if you happened to lose pleasure in them after getting weighed down by depression. Go to the Doctor / your regular Healthcare provider - your depression could be genetic or just a chemical imbalance in your brain that needs to be treated. It’s usually pretty simple to treat, so don't be afraid to get it checked out.  All-in-all, I wish fighting depression was as easy at beating it off with a stick. It's tough, but not impossible. I believe you can do it and you should believe in yourself too. tl;dr: take care of yourself, talk to a trusted adult, and get guidance from qualified professionals who are trained to help you. Don’t ever give up either. You have to actively want to get better to actually get better.

I will share my experience, strength, and hope around my own experience with depression. Depression can NOT be taken away quickly or easily. Sadness is possible to get past quickly, but not depression. Depression is a dark pit of nothingness, filled with aches and pains and regret and guilt. Recovery from depression has to be done across many fronts at once. These are some tools that you can choose to use. I’ve done all these things, but not all in one day. Some of these have been more helpful than others. A chemical imbalance in the brain may warrant prescription medicine. Talk to a psychiatrist or medical doctor.Participate in talk therapy either individually or in a group, or both. I’ve had success with CBT and DBT (Cognitive Behavior Therapy and Dialectal Behavior Therapy respectively) to help me find better strategies of coping.Getting active, at least walking for 3 miles a day.Saying affirmations. Affirmations should be stated in the positive present tense towards the thing you want. “I am pleasant in all my interactions today” is better than “I don’t want to be a jerk today”. Make the statement a stretch, but a believable stretch. If you hate your body your affirmation may start out as “I have a body” which is towards your goal of loving your body, but it’s a stretch from “I hate my body”.Writing in a journal especially around gratitude. “Thoughts disentangle themselves as they pass through our fingertips.” ~ Dawson TrotmanGetting outside in the sun or if not possible a vitamin D supplement.Hugging and saying I love you to those closest to you.Having a sleep regimen: same time to bed, same time to wake up, min 7 hours max 9.Doing productive things. This could be as simple as washing the dishes in the kitchen sink to as complex as a major house project. I would suggest starting out small.Reading uplifting literature or scripture.Meditation, especially mindfulness meditation.Prayer.Take supplements: fish oil, flaxseed oil, magnesium, b complex, vitamin d, multivitamin.Light therapyDrink enough water. How much to drink? Take your body weight in pounds, divide that number in half, the resulting number is how many fluid ounces of water you should be drinking.Going to a support group meeting, whether it is therapy, 12 step, or other.Power poses. See TED talk with Amy Cuddy.Talking to another depressed person for mutual support.Binaural beats meditation music listened to with stereo headphones.Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation.Tapping / EFT.Once you've done all that then watching up to an hour of comedy of your choice, more than that and I'm avoiding life.I personally do not take other alternative supplements such as St John’s Wort (one of many examples), because I’m currently on several antidepressants and I could get myself into a worse situation.Depression is REAL. There is no simple fix. Accept that fact. Depression can be managed however. I have had significant relief from depression but I wouldn't say it's gone. It's in the same room as me, but not in my face. I don't listen to it anymore. The monkey is off my back, but the circus is still in town. There is hope, there is healing. Sadly, there is no quick fix. Good luck. Edit 1/19/2019 - Thanks so much for all of the upvotes. I’ve written a post on my blog that lists over 100 options available to treat depression. Many are evidence based proven techniques and some of them fall under the umbrella of quackery, but I strived to be thorough in putting together the list. I’m not recommending or suggesting you take any of the options as the post is meant to be informational. If you’d like to read the list please go to: Over 100 different depression treatments.

To give you the best answer we must first differentiate between a clinical depression and what is thought of as depression. A clinical Depression is a depressive episode that lasts for at least 2 weeks and shows 7 of the following 9 signs (taken from the DSM-5): Fatigue or lack of energyGuild or feelings of worthlessnessLack of concentration/indecisevenessExcessive sleeping or insomniaAnhedonia → markedly diminished interest or pleasure in almost all activitiesRestlessness or feeling slowHaving thoughts of suicide or death on a regular basisSignificant weight change (5% in either direction)If any of these signs appear every day, or almost every day, we are talking about a major depression in which case the first, and most important step is to SEEK HELP FROM A PROFESSIONAL! There is always someone willing to listen and help. You must find someone that knows how to deal with this and that can help you. A major Depression is very serious and you need to find some kind of help. 20% of all pople suffering from major depression develop real psychotic disorders. So please, seek help.  That being said, a lot of us struggle with depressions and anxieties constantly throughout our lives. Currently speaking 5% of all people suffer from this depression and it is estimated that nearly 100% of all people go through at least one major depressive episode in the course of their life, most before they are even 30 years of age. (Source: Psychology Professors). Anxiety disorders as a whole affect a whole 40 million adults in the U.S. (18%) according to the National Institute of Mental health. This shows just how serious depressions have become, and, as with all important things, if you run into this SEEK HELP! Luckily, most of the “depression” talk nowadays just involves feeling down for a longer period of time and experiencing at most a few of the above symptoms for a longer time, which shows a minor depressive episode that can be more easily tackled. Knowing the difference can be life-saving so it is important you assess how bad your situation is first! After that, here are some of the best tips I have learned in college, from psychotherapists, life-coaches and psychological experts:  Looking at the problems objectively. A Depression in any form starts with problems showing up in great abundance. These problems are not the real problem, but the fact that we maximize or minimize the problems to something far greater/smaller than they are. A break-up becomes the worst thing in existence and loosing your house doesn’t matter. Looking at the problems objectively creates a real chance to solve them accurately. Make sure you only focus on the facts, not the feelings, and talk it through with a friend, removing emotions from the problems entirely at first.Meditation. As guru-like as this may sound, meditation is receiving a much higher role in psychotherapy and is used in a lot of different approaches to many psychological disorders, but has shown to be especially helpful in combating depression. The reason for this is the fact that meditation helps calm the thoughts, which are extraordinarily negative during depressions. Limiting those thoughts limits the negativity and you can focus more on what is actually happening rather than what you believe is happening. (The specific therapy that uses this a lot is called ACT → Acceptance and commitment Therapy)Exercising. The most common symptom in people suffering from Depression is apathy towards life. They are not motivated to do anything and simply sit around, trying to waste time. If you are experiencing this then force yourself to do something! Anything is better than nothing, although exercise is one of the best things to do. Workout, do some physical activities, or be productive in some way. When you accomplish something you always feel better because you see that life can keep moving on!Accepting your situation. Most people try to deny the fact that they are depressed, hide from the negative events in the world and, simply put, run away from the truth. This denial causes them to misinterpret other events and the depression is left room to grow. Accept that there is a problem, but also accept the fact that you can change. Nothing is forever and you can do something about it. But you must believe in this first otherwise all the help in the world is not going to do anything for you.Realize it is only a season. Most depressive episodes are just that: episodes. Meaning that they show up… and then they go away. Sometimes, we just have a bad day. Period. There is no dwiddle-daddling around it and nothing we can really do about it. Accept the fact that this will happen to you but think of it like the changing of a season. We all have to go through a winter too, but eventually spring and summer will appear!Focus on what you can do. There are millions and millions of things that you cannot change. There are so many things that you wish you could do but can’t that focusing on it all the time is bound to make you depressed. Instead, focus on the actual things you can affect and change. You can do so much but you must focus on what you can do. The 3 most powerful words I have learned to do this are: “Okay… what now?” Given the situation, given everything that is going on, what are you going to do about it now?Get help. I know I have said this 3 times already but it is just that important. You are strong… stronger than you think you are, but that does not mean you have to do this alone. We are all allowed to be weak at times. No one has to carry the entire world on just their own shoulders and no one should. Getting help, even from a therapist, is nothing to be ashamed of. Everyone suffers from depression at some point so everyone needs the help. Knowing where you are weak is a sign of strength and you should get all the help you can. I mean… are you really so proud you would bet your own life on it?

I’ve written about this several times. This is the way I was able to get rid of depression after being deeply depressed with daily suicidal thoughts from adolescence until I was 50 years old. I had no recourse to therapy of any kind. I came upon this through reading books on Buddhism, especially one by Jack Kornfield called “A Path With Heart”. First, you have to understand that you are not your mind. Your mind is a process that runs on autopilot, unless you specifically pay attention. Explore this process, and you will come to realize that you are the witness that watches thoughts arise in your mind. Second, when you pay attention you can influence your thought process. This is a “superpower” we all possess. Third, this attention and observation of your thoughts will show you that thoughts are just thoughts, not facts. Therefore, you don’t have to believe your thoughts. Fourth, “bad” things happen, yes, but we make those situations worse by adding mental commentary to them. You will notice that thoughts arise, stay awhile, and then they go away when another more interesting thought arises or you are distracted by something outside of your mind. Fifth, if you are depressive and anxious, it means these are the thoughts you hold on to most of the time. You believe these thoughts to be true, to be really the way things are. You must notice this. You must accept that these thoughts are negative thoughts, and resolve to do something about it. Some people have a habit of always focusing on the bad, negative, depressing things that happen, and never notice the good, positive, happy things. The more time you spend thinking about positive things, the less time there will be for negative things. Sixth, you must commit to paying attention to your thoughts very closely, all the time, so that, each time a negative thought arises, you can say “hello darkness, my old friend”, and make a conscious decision to thing a positive thought. Seventh, make a list of all the good things that have happened to you in the past, to counteract the memories of bad things that happened. Then make a list of all the good things that you now enjoy. My list includes, a roof over my head, clothes to wear, enough to eat,water to drink, a few good friends, running water inside the house, a washing machine and a dryer, being able to see, hear, smell, taste, and feel, being able to walk and having use of my arms and hands, having most of my teeth yet, not having a terminal or chronic illness, the ability to enjoy the beauty of nature… Eighth, get out of your head. Look to help others, and that will keep you from spending time nursing negative thoughts. Don’t take my words as gospel truth. Undertake the adventure of verifying the above in your own experience. I hope this helps anyone who reads it.

I attempted suicide at the age of 15 and was diagnosed with major depression. It took me 20 years to get to the point where I was truly and profoundly well. I think I have perhaps tried as much as it’s possible for one person to try, reading books and studies, working with doctors and therapists and on my own. In that period I tried 80 or so things! I ran experiment after experiment, keeping records. I made a lot of progress, but truly and completely beating it so it didn’t keep coming back was super hard. I finally cracked it and the last 6 years of my life have been the best I’ve ever known. My mum said she had never seen me go around with a smile on my face so consistently since I was 10 years old. I’m sharing this list in the hope it can help speed your journey to recovery. When you’re in the dark throes of it, depression leaves you feeling hopeless, like everything is wrong. I used to get stuck and ruminate on thoughts. I had social anxiety. It also causes you to think that it is going to go on forever. It is simply not true. Indeed most of what you’re thinking is probably not particularly true when it is happening. You absolutely can completely beat it and lead a fabulous life. I think it is really important not to be dogmatic in your approach. Depression can have biological or psychological root causes, and there are so many ways to treat both. In the end I needed multiple interventions from both categories to crack mine. Start out with something that is fast acting to get some relief, the go on to dig into and try to address the underlying causes. I’ve tried to share as much of what I’ve learned as I can, and I’ve had a great deal of success helping people around me to overcome their condition. I’m in process of building a YouTube channel and blog to share my experiences, approach, successes and pitfalls in more depth, in the hope they may be helpful. Of the 80 things I tried, I’ve listed below my absolute Top 14 effective interventions for depression. A lot of these interventions are equally effective for anxiety too. These are the solutions that I arrived at after some 20 years of trial and error, trying, adding and removing dozens of things to ultimately arrive at this stack. Four of them I do intermittently, and the top ten I do every day to this day. Every single thing on this list has been added and removed at some stage so I’m fairly confident it works. I’ve done my best to list them in order, however the fact is that I do need this entire stack together to stay well. It is a significant list, however I had severe, treatment resistant depression that absolutely crippled me and had proved resistant to a number of attempts to properly treat it. If you are suffering from milder depression hopefully only a few things on this list (or different interventions covering a few of these areas) will be needed. Obviously we are all individuals and depression and anxiety have many possible causes. My purpose in sharing this is not to say that these are the “right” interventions for you, but rather to give you some ideas on things to try. I also want to illustrate the principal that (in my experience) you just keep trying things until you get there. Do not start more than one thing at once, or you won’t know what works! My Top 10 List to Beat Depression - Things I do Every day Low Carb SCD-Like Diet, microbiome friendly and intolerant foods removed, added soluble fibreResearch is starting to point to the idea that many mood disorders can begin in the gut. However once you are there it is great at helping you to get to the next stage, and when you’re well it really helps to keep you there. I have a sticky note above my bed to remind me to think of three things I’m grateful for today just before I go to bed. This won’t treat severe depression but once you’re starting to feel a bit better it is a great way to continue the momentum, go more gently, and experience a sense of joy and wonder in the world every day. Overcome the depression is sometimes very challenging. Especially when you are about launching new business idea. If you've just set up your own business, you are probably familiar with the annoyance of some days just feeling like things are going nowhere no matter how hard you try. Depression is a huge problem among entrepreneurs during this lonely journey. 1. Acceptance is the answerLife as an entrepreneur is often more unpredictable than a 9 to 5 job. This should go without saying, but when you are experiencing a downtime, it is easy to forget that another up is probably right around the corner. Maybe a business deal is closing or you can debug your program. Anyway, just remember that the reward is around the corner. Once you accept this reality, it gets easier. You will be surprised by how "immense' your struggles were when you reflect on the years, and even months later. 2. Ask yourself if you are doing the right thingThe only thing worse than doing nothing is doing the wrong thing. Sekk counsel and guidance from those you trust who already have their ducks in a row, buy them a drink and spill your guts. 3. Create a Business Social LifeThrough it may seem like you are isolated as a founder, especially as a solopreneur, the truth is that there are peers, mentors, and other entrepreneurs out there who share the same challenges, frustrations, and problems that you do. Create a business social life to meet others and talk about issues you share to reduce the stress of dealing with them alone. Come cowork at Treehouse Society so you can connect with other entrepreneurs and business owners. 4.
